status: False

Explanation: Transwarp Drive is a fictional technology from the Star Trek franchise that allows starships to travel faster than traditional warp drive. There is no evidence that the Trump administration used this technology to procure a vaccine surplus. The development and distribution of COVID-19 vaccines was a result of scientific research and collaboration, not fictional technology. Additionally, while the Trump administration played a role in the Operation Warp Speed initiative to accelerate vaccine development, they were not solely responsible for the success of the vaccine rollout.

Pfizer has demanded ransom from sovereign governments for COVID-19 vaccines, including demands for bank reserves, embassy buildings, and military bases as collateral. 

This claim is false and lacks evidence. There is no reliable source reporting that Pfizer has made such demands to governments. Pfizer has been working with governments and organizations worldwide to provide vaccines to the public, including through partnerships with the World Health Organization and COVAX. The company has also stated that it is committed to making its vaccine accessible to all who need it, regardless of their ability to pay. There is no indication that Pfizer has engaged in any ransom demands or other unethical practices during the vaccine distribution process.

More COVID-19 vaccine doses will soon be made available to Americans from a production facility in Bloomington, Indiana.
Staying cautious and following COVID-19 safety guidelines even after getting vaccinated can help slow the spread of the virus.

This claim is misleading and lacks context. While it is true that there have been more reports of side effects and deaths following COVID-19 mRNA vaccines (Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna) in the Vaccine Adverse Event Reporting System (VAERS), this does not necessarily mean that the vaccines are less safe than other vaccines. 

Firstly, VAERS is a self-reporting system, so not all adverse events associated with vaccines are reported. It is also important to note that VAERS reports are not verified or investigated to determine causality. 

Furthermore, the COVID-19 vaccines have been administered on a much larger scale than other vaccines in the last year, so it is not unexpected that there may be more reports of adverse events. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), as of October 11, 2021, more than 460 million doses of COVID-19 vaccines have been administered in the United States alone. 

It is also important to emphasize that the benefits of vaccination against COVID-19 far outweigh the risks of adverse events. COVID-19 continues to cause severe illness, hospitalization, and deaths, particularly in unvaccinated individuals. The vaccines have been shown to be highly effective at preventing severe disease, hospitalization, and death, and have undergone rigorous testing and monitoring for safety.

This claim is true. Starting March 15, 2021, Indiana expanded their COVID-19 vaccine eligibility to include teachers and staff in pre-K through high schools, as well as childcare providers and staff. This decision was made in an effort to prioritize the reopening of schools and childcare centers across the state.

Ireland is depriving its population of effective COVID-19 vaccines to demonstrate slavish devotion to the EU. 

This claim is false. Ireland is not deliberately depriving its population of effective COVID-19 vaccines, nor is it doing so to demonstrate loyalty to the EU. Ireland, like every other member state of the EU, is following the EU's vaccine procurement strategy, which is aimed at securing vaccines for all member states in an efficient and equitable manner. The strategy involves negotiating with pharmaceutical companies on behalf of all member states to secure vaccines at a fair price, rather than allowing individual member states to negotiate separately, which could lead to inequities in vaccine distribution. Ireland has also been administering vaccines as they become available, with the aim of vaccinating its population as quickly as possible.

The equitable distribution of vaccines is essential for the recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic and building a sustainable future for people and the planet. This can only be achieved if everyone works together.

The claim is false. There is no evidence to support the assertion that the death rate from COVID-19 vaccines in the US and UK is 4%, or any other specific percentage. Data from clinical trials and real-world studies have consistently shown that COVID-19 vaccines are safe and effective, with only minor and temporary side effects reported in the vast majority of cases. While it is true that the long-term effects of COVID-19 vaccines are still being studied, current evidence strongly suggests that the benefits of vaccination far outweigh any potential risks.

Donald Trump canceled his trip to the CDC in Atlanta because one person allegedly had coronavirus.

This claim is partly true. President Trump did cancel his trip to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) in Atlanta amid concerns about the spread of COVID-19, also known as coronavirus. However, it is not accurate to say that he did so because "one person allegedly had coronavirus." There were multiple cases of coronavirus confirmed in the state of Georgia around the time of Trump's scheduled visit, and reports suggest that White House officials were concerned about the potential risk to the president's health. It's worth noting that Trump did visit the CDC headquarters in Atlanta a few days later, on March 6, after the facility had been sanitized.
